node.title: Charles Perkins Oration: Why truth-telling and treaties are needed to reconcile Australia's past
node.alt: A man waring a suit is leaning on a desk that has a judges wig on it
node.description: Tony McAvoy SC has used the 2021 Charles Perkins Memorial Oration to advocate for the establishment of truth commissions and treaties with Australia's First Peoples, labelling the often-used assertion that Aboriginal people should 'stop living in the past' as "not possible".
node.content:
["Tony McAvoy SC,\u00a0the country's most senior Aboriginal barrister, used the 2021 Charles Perkins Memorial Oration to advocate for the establishment of truth commissions and treaties with Australia's First Peoples, labelling the often-used assertion that Aboriginal people should \"stop living in the past\"\u00a0as \"not possible\".", "\"Our past, our connection to these lands and waters is such a profoundly spiritual affair that our identity and wellbeing depends on the maintenance and transmission of these connections,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "Since 2000, the Dr Charles Perkins Oration and Prize \u2014 hosted by the University of Sydney \u2014 has provided a distinguished platform for the discussion of race relations in Australia.", "The event has also allowed for perceived injustices and inequalities experienced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be brought to the attention of the broader Australian public, just as was achieved in 1965 when Charles Perkins led a bus tour across NSW, known as the Freedom Rides.", "
An extraordinary moment
", "", "
Charles Perkins talking with Aboriginal residents in Moree, NSW, during the Freedom Ride in 1965.(Supplied: State Library of NSW)
", "Inspired by the American Civil Rights Movement, the Freedom Rides provided a glimpse into the poor state of Aboriginal health, education, and housing in remote and regional communities.", "\"Charles Perkins was an extraordinary person, a person who achieved greatness in his lifetime and stood at the frontline of our conflicts with the government and racists in this country,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "Stops in Walgett, where Aboriginal people could not enter the RSL, and Moree, which excluded Aboriginal children from swimming in the local pool, attracted national media coverage.", "Through his outspoken and sometimes controversial advocacy, Charles Perkins challenged Australia to confront its own history that he felt it was previously unwilling to do, sparking debate and opportunities for change.", "\"His legacy lives on through his contributions to education, sport, housing, and public life,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "In recent years, encouraging the broader Australian public to take an interest in Indigenous Affairs has proven both difficult and problematic, commonly punctuated by calls for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to take personal agency and forge successful and prosperous lives within modern Australia.", "Mr McAvoy would use his address to push back against such statements by outlining the intergenerational impacts of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander dispossession.", "
Massacres of the Kalkadoon
", "", "
Kalkadoon people were killed in a raid now known as the \"Battle Mountain\"\u00a0massacre.(Supplied)
", "The post-colonial history of the Kalkadoon People of north-west Queensland, (the paternal ancestral country of Charles Perkins) was central to Mr McAvoy's oration as he outlined the parallel yet entirely disparate experiences of Kalkadoon people to that of European settlers.", "\"Following the attempted eradication of the Kalkadoon, Mt Isa became a prosperous regional centre where the British could engage in mining and grazing without fear,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "The territory of the Kalkadoon People is a vast tract of land in what is now known as north-western Queensland which includes the inland city of Mount Isa. Their country straddles the Leichhardt River and includes the Selwyn Range to the east.", "A barrister specialising in native title and\u00a0human rights, and the country's first Indigenous silk, Mr McAvoy worked with the Kalkadoon people as counsel for their native title claim in the late 2000s.", "\"It was during the 1860s that the British came to understand that there was copper-oxide in the Mt Isa area, after being shown by some Kalkadoon people. The British took up government grants of tenure on the lands of the Kalkadoon, and conflict ensued,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "In an effort to protect their land, the Kalkadoon used, \"a very successful form of guerilla warfare, engaging in surprise attacks and then retreating to the rocky mountain range where the British could not find them\".", "", "
A memorial plaque at Battle Mountain.(Supplied)
", "In 1884, as tensions continued to escalate, Native Police troops stationed at Normanton massacred the Kalkadoon people in a dawn raid now known as the \"Battle Mountain\"\u00a0massacre.", "\"Approximately 900 Kalkatungu were killed in that battle and the six years prior,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "During the Kalkadoon's Native Title claim, Mr McAvoy heard perspectives of these events from an elder who had been told, first hand, of the \"Battle Mountain\"\u00a0massacre by his grandmother.", "\"The two sides of the battle had very different trajectories following Battle Mountain. The Kalkadoon people were largely massacred, with survivors significantly displaced and living lives of destitution and oppression. And the British side, well, their lives flourished,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "In December 2011, the Kalkadoon people had their native title rights recognised by the Federal Court of Australia, providing them with decision-making powers over land use, economic development and care of the environment.", "
Truth commissions and treaties
", "", "
Mr McAvoy says the history of frontier wars should be a part of the national school curriculum.
", "Frontier violence and colonial tension is a familiar story for Indigenous people and communities nationwide, who all bear the scars of dispossession in some form or another.", "In recent years there has been a growing acceptance and willingness to better understand the nuances of Australia's shared history, but Mr McAvoy said Indigenous perspectives have historically been overlooked by mainstream institutions and teachings.", "\"It is a story that deserves to hold a position in the national narrative alongside the Gallipoli and Kokoda Track. It should be a part of the national school curriculum. But it is not,\" Mr McAvoy said.", "To combat this absence, Mr McAvoy is proposing the implementation of \"social structures\" in the form of truth and treaty commissions.", "\"The gap between exploitative destruction of the landscape in the name of the economy and the deep spirituality of our First Nations is far too great, social structures need to be built to allow us to be safe and happy and allow us to shape our own destiny,\" he said.", "Truth-telling commissions are formal bodies tasked with discovering and revealing past wrongdoings in the hope of resolving conflict and repairing relationships. However, Aboriginal stories of survival, success and aspiration are also to be shared.", "It remains unclear how Mr McAvoy's proposals would operate or be implemented but Victoria's Yoo-rrook Justice Commission is one example of a seemingly workable model.", "The truth-telling commission is an agreement between the Victorian government and the First Peoples' Assembly of Victoria, an elected representative body of Traditional Owners and other Victorian Aboriginal people. It's expected to hand down its interim report in June 2022.", "", "
Charles Perkins and other members of the Freedom Ride at Bowraville, NSW, in 1965.(Supplied:\u00a0State Library of New South Wales)
", "In months ahead there is sure to be further pressure to explain how truth-telling and treaty are more than symbolic gestures which will do little to improve the social-economic standing of Indigenous people, but in the meantime, Mr McAvoy is resolute in pressing ahead with a sentiment similar to that of Perkins, one of self-determination, governance and community control.", "\"It cannot be that we continue to see our people dying of preventable disease, incarcerated at shocking rates, impoverished and treated like some inferior class. It is time to move beyond the colony.\"", "The 2021 Dr Charles Perkins Memorial Oration will be broadcast on ABC TV and ABC Iview, Saturday, November 12 at 12:30pm."]
